abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Highlands Water
            Project Phase 1A was rated as satisfactory. The lessons
            learned include: 1) The project demonstrates that the Bank
            can play a unique role and add significant value even when
            it finances only a small portion of project costs. 2) The
            project illustrates two factors that require careful
            consideration when designing and implementing transnational
            projects. First, there must be clear and equitable sharing
            of costs and benefits, and second, there needs to be a
            separation of governance and oversight functions from
            implementation. 3) The project underscores the risks
            associated with establishing a new agency for implementing a
            particular project, especially a high-profile operation such
            as this. 4) The project illustrates the benefits that can be
            derived from appropriate expert input into implementation.
            Both the engineering and the environmental Panel of Experts
            provided valuable recommendations that impacted on the
            design of these components and resulted in significant
            savings. 5) Problems experienced in implementing the
            project's environmental and social program point
            towards the importance of advance planning, including the
            preparation of sound Environmental Impact Assessments and of
            Environmental Action Plans prior to project start-up, to
            ensure that these components get off to a timely and
            effective start.
